p:
Several insects have developed extraordinary capacity to survive exposure to xenobiotics normally designed to manage them
40 . Furthermore, insects harbor a wide variety of gut symbionts
2, 41, 42 , which play pivotal roles in their adaptation to the environment following exposure to pesticides
19, 43 . In an attempt to reduce the incidence of insecticide resistance in C. maculatus, coupled with the necessity of developing an alternative control strategy, we tested the hypothesis that gut microbiota of C. maculatus are involved in its resistance to dichlorvos and L. adoensis EO could break this resistance and enhance the susceptibility of the beetle across generations.
